summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The records are from an address book belonging to Jeffrey Epstein that Rodriguez attempted to sell, which is believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He was Epstein's former house manager and butler who came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: The individual whose former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for Epstein's additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

Rodriguez possessed an address book belonging to Epstein containing information on potential underage victims and attempted to sell it rather than provide it to authorities, implicating him in the obstruction of justice related to Epstein's case.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division of the FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records collection
events.description: The document notes telephone records were generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 23, 2010) for cases that are now closed, indicating the scope of records being processed.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (Address of FBI Document Conversion Laboratory)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and telephone numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.

Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas, leading to an FBI obstruction of justice case against him opened in October 2009.

The FBI is processing telephone records from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for incorporation into the Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.
The document is a formal request for the FBI's Document Conversion Laboratory to scan, automate, and format these records, indicating a systematic evidence processing effort within the Bureau.

The records are considered unclassified, and the processing involves specific protocols for handling evidence, including coordination with an Evidence Control Technician and procedures for handling classified media.
